title: Cryptography Basics
description: Test your knowledge of cryptographic concepts, algorithms, and protocols. This quiz covers encryption, hashing, digital signatures, and cryptographic attacks.

questions.text: What is the difference between symmetric and asymmetric encryption?

answers.text: Symmetric encryption uses one key for both encryption and decryption, while asymmetric encryption uses different keys for encryption and decryption
Symmetric encryption is always more secure than asymmetric encryption
Asymmetric encryption is always faster than symmetric encryption
There is no difference; they are two terms for the same thing

questions.text: Which of the following is a symmetric encryption algorithm?

answers.text: RSA
AES
ECC
Diffie-Hellman

questions.text: Which of the following is an asymmetric encryption algorithm?

answers.text: AES
DES
3DES
RSA
A function that converts input data of any size into a fixed-size output
A function that encrypts data
A function that decrypts data
A function that compresses data for storage

questions.text: Which of the following is a cryptographic hash function?

answers.text: AES
RSA
SHA-256
Diffie-Hellman
A handwritten signature that has been scanned
A cryptographic mechanism that provides authentication, non-repudiation, and integrity
A type of encryption algorithm
A password that uses special characters

questions.text: What is the purpose of a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)?

answers.text: To provide free encryption services
To manage public keys and digital certificates
To break encryption for law enforcement
To speed up encryption processes
A government agency that regulates encryption
A trusted entity that issues digital certificates
A software program that encrypts data
A hardware device that stores encryption keys

questions.text: What is a brute force attack in cryptography?

answers.text: An attack that uses social engineering to obtain encryption keys
An attack that exploits vulnerabilities in encryption algorithms
An attack that tries all possible keys or passwords until the correct one is found
An attack that physically damages encryption devices

questions.text: What is forward secrecy in cryptography?

answers.text: A property that ensures past communications cannot be decrypted if the long-term key is compromised
A technique to predict future encryption keys
A method to encrypt data for future use
A way to ensure encryption keys are never lost
